item.title: Ticket #2301 (Edit Pages - Limit to Owner?) created
item.dc:creator: gregkaufmanwp
item.description:
It was easy to limit page editing only to the page owner in 1.5. I have the Role Manager plugin installed in WP 2.0, and I'm trying to figure out how to enable the edit_pages role in 2.0 for a user, but not allow that user the ability edit ALL pages. This functionality exists for edit posts (edit_others_posts), but what about pages?

I understand this isn't an issue with the plugin, rather this is a major shortcoming of WP 2.0, in terms of being able to use WordPress as a CMS. It doesn't seem like it would be a big deal to have create a capability "edit_others_pages" similar to edit_others_posts. This would allow user access control as needed when using WordPress 2.0 as a CMS.

item.title: no-php.diff attached to Ticket #2300
item.dc:creator: skeltoac

item.title: Ticket #2300 (Privilege Escalation Vulnerability in File Upload handling) created
item.dc:creator: doit-cu
item.description:
Description: It is possible to upload and execute arbitrary PHP code via the inline uploads section of the write posts area. This can lead, among other things, to privilege escelation.

Exploit: Please contact webmaster@… if you require a working proof of concept. This proof of concept makes all users of any wordpress 2.0 installation administrators. I will not release this code until this problem has been addressed. Exploit code will only be provided to those working on solving the problem; otherwise, don't ask.

Solution: Possible work around is to do a RemoveHandler in an .htaccess file in the uploads directory: RemoveHandler .php for instance. However, if you have defined more than just .php as PHP code in an apache configuration, you will need to add those filetypes to the RemoveHandler directive.

Better solution is to disallow uploading of PHP handled filetypes unless the wordpress user is an administrator.

item.title: Ticket #2295 (HTML characters for greater than and less than converted incorrectly ...) closed
item.dc:creator: skeltoac
item.description:
invalid:

Works as planned. The rich editor's help window explains the use of less-than/greater than. Yes, it's tricky. How do we know what the user intends? If you can write a COMPLETE, CONCISE spec for how WYSIWYG should handle user-entered HTML, and it can be coded WITHOUT a state machine, reopen.

This is my spec proposal as a person who's tired of dealing with mind-reading bugs: WHAT YOU SEE IS WHAT YOU GET. YOU TYPE <img src="foo" /> YOU SEE <img src="foo" /> YOU GET <img src="foo" />, NOT AN IMAGE. However, that pisses more people off. So we compromise and the loser is the person who can't figure out how to show <. Keep playing with it, you'll figure it out and you'll get used to it. Hint: it depends on context.

Sorry about the unabashedly brazen reaction. It's not personal.

item.title: preg_replace.php attached to Ticket #2299
item.dc:creator: nielshackius
item.description: ExampleSkript, with different kind of paths-names (even with errors)

item.title: Ticket #2299 (plugin_basename doesn't return plugin_name within a fold in a correct way.) created
item.dc:creator: nielshackius
item.description:
to add an activation action for your plugin, internally add_action('activate_{pluginname}',$function) is used.

If your plugin is within a folder its name should be: "plugin/starthere.php" so it would be add_action('activate_plugin/starthere.php',$function). Currently, however not a slash, but a backslash is returned by plugin_basename, which breaks register_activation_hook.

Fix could be: 

$file= preg_replace('!\\\\+|/+!', '/', $file); //replaces even multiple backlslashes or multiple slashes by a single slash
$file= preg_replace('!^.*wp-content/plugins/!', '', $file); //removes anything before the file name

See also attaced example skript.

item.title: Ticket #2298 (add_role(), capabilties.php typo otherwise plugins might not work as ...) created
item.dc:creator: nielshackius
item.description:
In wp-includes/capabilities.php in line 325 is: 

return $wp_roles->add_role($role, $display_name, $capabilities = '');

but really should be, since capabilties is really set locally by the functions 

return $wp_roles->add_role($role, $display_name, $capabilities);

If not: The third argument of add_role won't work as expected.

item.title: Ticket #2277 (Ditch RDF and RSS 0.92) updated
item.dc:creator: ear1grey
item.description:
I agree with the concern over bloat, but suggesting RDF should be dropped because "readers these days are built to understand one or both of [Atom or RSS2]" is akin to arguing that IMAP or POP should be dropped from all mail servers - the protocols serve totally different audiences.

Ditch RDF and WP loses the "semantic markup" part of "WordPress is a state-of-the-art semantic personal publishing platform" - having RDF available means that WP content can be more easily integrated with Semantic Web enhanced applications - it's a low hanging fruit which (IMO) should be kept available because it's user base is significantly different to the users of Atom or RSS.

Basically RDF makes wordpress more attractive as an experimental platform.

The suggestion that "they've been bloating the WordPress core for too long" is fair enough, so long as it's also levelled at RSS2 and Atom - should they not ALL be plugins?

item.title: Ticket #2297 (printr does not properly clean up after itself) created
item.dc:creator: doit-cu
item.description:
I'm not sure what the purpose of this funtion is (print_r accepts a bool which does the same thing...). However, this function does not properly cleanup the ob portion. You need to add ob_clean_end(); on line 47 of functions-compat.php in order to fix this. ob_starts can be nested, but ob_clean_end only ends the top most ob_start, so if you were to ob_start outside this funtion, ob_clean_end inside the function would not kill that ob_start (only the one inside the function). Not ending output buffering inside the function makes it a bloody pain to try to debug your code.

Thank you, --Joel

item.title: link-import.patch attached to Ticket #2296

item.description: link-import.php patch to manage opml_url value equaling "​http://"

item.title: Ticket #2296 (link-import.php fails on default ompl_url value) created
item.dc:creator: Kafkaesqui
item.description:
With the default opml_url value (http://), link-import.php generates the following error, even if a local file is provided for upload:

Warning: fopen(http://): failed to open stream: No error in c:\inetpub\wwwroot\wp-includes\functions.php on line 2113

Submitting patch that assures opml_url doesn't also equal 'http://'.

item.title: Ticket #2295 (HTML characters for greater than and less than converted incorrectly ...) created
item.dc:creator: joebolte
item.description:
The implementation of entering "less than" and "greater than" symbols (and possibly other HTML character entities) is broken in the edit page. Entering < or > in the Rich Editor does not create < or > in the HTML page. Entering < or > in the HTML editor causes the ampersand to be encoded as an HTML entity, so that the character is not displayed correctly in the rich editor or the final displayed page or post.

As a result of this bug, the only way to get < or > to display on a page is to leave those actual characters in the HTML so that un-validated HTMl displays.

item.description:

Old Code:
$numcomments = $wpdb->get_var("SELECT COUNT(*) FROM $tablecomments WHERE comment_approved = '0'");

New Code:
$numcomments = $wpdb->get_var("SELECT COUNT(*) FROM $wpdb->comments WHERE comment_approved = '0'");

item.title: Ticket #2291 (When you have some FF extensions installed TinyMCEs popups are too narrow) closed
item.dc:creator: skeltoac
item.description:
invalid:

User config problem, not a bug in WordPress or TinyMCE.

I'm using SessionSaver. I just checked for updates and there were none. I do not have this problem. It looks to me like a configuration issue and not something that can be fixed in TinyMCE.

That window is supposed to be a modal window, not treated the same as other browser windows. Browser extensions should know better than to treat it the same. Unfortunately, I don't think there's anything we can do to get around a bad extension.

item.title: tiny_mce_popup.gif attached to Ticket #2291
item.dc:creator: simonwheatley
item.description: Screengrab of the issue with SearchStatus enabled.

item.title: Ticket #2291 (When you have some FF extensions installed TinyMCEs popups are too narrow) updated
item.dc:creator: simonwheatley
item.description: SessionSaver "dl * nightly 30" appears to fix the issue for that extension.

item.title: Ticket #2291 (When you have some FF extensions installed TinyMCEs popups are too narrow) created
item.dc:creator: simonwheatley
item.description:
Running FF1.5 with SessionSaver 0.2.1.030.4 and/or SearchStatus 1.14 and WP2.0 the TinyMCE "edit link" popup is too narrow. Disabling the extensions fixes this issue.

These extension versions appear to be the most recent.

+1 to ditch Atom too. Atom is a dead end technology. MS, AOL and Yahoo all chose RSS. Google is providing RSS and Atom. Plus, having several formats confuses users, and I cannot name a single feed reader who cannot understand both formats.

item.title: Ticket #2288 (Reenable cache for safe_mode hosts) updated
item.dc:creator: davidhouse
item.description:
Keywords changed

Agreed, there shouldn't be a blanket condition there. Could we change 

if (ini_get('safe_mode'))

to 

if (ini_get('safe_mode') && get_option('safe_mode_no_cache'))

Then people with safe mode, who knew what they were doing, could just pop over to wp-admin/options.php (we wouldn't display this option by default in the admin) and change it to true?

item.title: Ticket #2287 (embed content stripped when posting through XML-RPC) created
item.dc:creator: RandomNumbers
item.description: I have used Audioblog.com in previous vrsions to embed audio into posts. Since upgrading to 2.0, audioblog posts are stripped of everything but the text, rendering them useless for their purpose. Something in the WP2.0 is stripping the embedded player from posts made through XML-RPC from outside.
